ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Question 1 - - Many of the readings were fantastic and thought-provoking, however a few (maybe one or two per week) could be weeded out.Question 4 - - This course was a lot of work because of all the reading. However, because it was such a small seminar, the work payed off.Question 7 - - Os and Willis were fantastic and really added a ton to the course. Specifically, I thought they were both good at really facilitating good discussion and pushing us much harder than most professors do in that sort of context.Question 8 - - This was one of the best courses I've ever taken, and definitely one of the best I've taken at FES.Question 10 - - Despite leaving me with more questions than I started, this course was very useful in helping me think about environmentalism and ethics broadly.
This course is structured as a seminar, and both Os and Willis are extremely effective at facilitating focused discussion.

Os and Willis' expert facilitationThe mix of FES and Divinity School students - - and the high level of conversation brought by the specific 11 students in the classHow it made me think hard about all my other courses, past and present, in a new light.I really found myself looking forward to this course every week.

From the start, this class had fantastic, rigorous, and illuminating conversations. Everyone was highly engaged- both the professors and all the students. It was a small seminar- 11 students, 2 professors- and something just seemed to click. Students felt free to take risks with their interpretations of the readings and the professors not only listened but responded thoughtfully and respectfully. I loved it.
It started to question many of the assumptions we make in conservation, which is important for those who are dedicating their professional lives based on such assumptions

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: More effort needs to be placed on developing the basic knowledge to engage in these high-order discussions. I feel I haven't really come away with a good knowledge of broad ethical approaches, language, concepts

As mentioned above, a few readings could be weeded out to lighten the load slightly and concentrate on the better readings.Though both professors were great facilitators, Willis was definitely better at leading discussions and not letting things stagnate, as they did once in a while under Os' leadership.I would've liked to be able to submit a draft of my paper (had that option, at least) maybe a few weeks or month before it was due for comments from Os and Willis. I know that adds more work, but it seems appropriate given that it is50% of the grade. I felt I pushed myself hard on my paper, but I would've liked to take it even further.

The strange thing about this seminar is that somewhere, we lost the thread. It's like we were all running together, not without effort but fast and strong, but somehow didn't notice that we had run straight off a cliff. I honestly felt like the bottom fell out. Maybe we needed to spend a class, or even two, on pulling together all the avenues of thinking we had pursued? Maybe producing two shorter papers instead of one long one would have kept my thought process intact? I don't know. I did feel that there were way too many readings assigned throughout the semester and that I would have preferred for us to focus on fewer readings and really discuss them in depth as opposed to racing through each of them. I know that each professor has to grapple with this issue but that doesn't necessarily diminish the feeling. I also still feel like I have no handle on ethics, I mean, none whatsoever, and though this wasn't an intro to ethics class, I felt ill equipped for the challenge.
There needs to be more lectures given by the professors that lay some groundwork and provide a vocabulary to the students before discussion begins.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both professors were engaged in the material and active forces in shaping the direction of the dialogue. Both are effective at facilitating discussion - Willis is extremely strong in this manner. It did not devolve into an unstructured arena for people shooting off their opinions -the discussions remained quite focused throughout the semester.
Both professors were willing to meet and very helpful when we did.
Both the professors were available for meetings any time we wanted to schedule one.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Again, the course question many of the unsaid and unchallenged assumptions in conservation that truly do effect how management and conservation is done.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: This new course intrigued me; I welcomed the opportunity to hear perspectives outside FES
To expand my idea of environmentalism.
I was interested in using the framework of ethics to help me further understand the natural resource issues I focus on.
I wanted to prepare myself for decision making in the professional world

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: The course was challenging and thought-provoking, as I anticipated. The seminar style worked quite effectively

Above and beyond. Often, I find that seminar courses can fall flat from lack of leadership on the professor's part and lack of preparation on the students' parts. This did not - - it exceeded my expectations.
In the beginning, it exceeded my expectations and at the end, I was a little disappointed.
It surpassed my expectations

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes, though I thought we might hear more about every person's personal thoughts/ideas/beliefs a bit more than we did. Perhaps the professors can make sure to make room for that kind of exchange.
In some ways, no. I did not think the course would go as deep as it did. It was a very different type of ethics discussion than I've had in other courses that had smaller sections on ethics.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The group work was minor, and wasn't a big component of this course.
Working with a Divinity School student provided a real opportunity for cross-disciplinary exchange and thought. We talk so much about it, so to actually do it was very, very exciting and rewarding.

This was the first time that my partner and I brought almost completely non-overlapping skills and knowledge to the table and merged them into a single concept and thesis. This is how group work should be done.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The reading load is quite heavy, but it is worth it to stay up on it. You will get more out of the discussions the more you have read.
Dothe reading, enjoy the discussions, don't pick your paper topic too early in case your ideas expand and change over the course of the semester.
Keep up on the terminology and background. Ask for clarification on basic concepts if you do not have a background in ethics.
